Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: A New PhD Program in Wind Energy Science, Engineering and Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the development of a new multidisciplinary, multi-institutional graduate training program of education and research in Wind Energy Science, Engineering and Policy (WESEP), at Iowa State University, in collaboration with the University of Puerto Rico - Mayag√ºez. The purpose of this program is to provide doctoral students with multidisciplinary training in the skills required for conducting research at the disciplinary interface between engineering, atmospheric science/meteorology, agriculture/economics, and journalism/communication.

Intellectual Merit: The thematic basis is that mitigating global climate change requires energy system transformation to reduce greenhouse gases from the electric sector; wind energy must play a central role in this, which will occur only through interdisciplinary leadership in advancing pertinent science, engineering, technology and policy. The vision is to strengthen the nation?s wind energy resources by producing technical experts, effective communicators, and ethical decision-makers who lead the U.S. transformation to a high-wind energy portfolio. The research will increase wind energy growth rate, decreasing its cost, and extend its penetration limits. Our education program includes a 3-6 month industry internship, a 3-month international experience, and a 3-level curriculum to provide breadth, interdisciplinary research strength, and advanced training and depth in WESEP. Trainees and faculty will experience the full research cycle every semester via participation in our real-time research collaborative. We will ensure that 30% of our IGERT student population is from underrepresented groups. Broader Impacts: This project will have near- and long-term impact on increasing supply of cost-effective clean energy, fundamental engineering and science, and energy policy.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, an NSF-sponsored Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) focused on wind energy, provided a large infusion of Ph.D-level engineering, science, and policy-related talent to the US as our nation increasingly relies on renewable energy production to supply our electrical needs. The intellectual merit of this work is contained in the development of a new Ph. D. degree program at Iowa State University (ISU) in Wind Energy Science, Engineering and Policy (WESEP), the 28 Ph.D. students who participated in this program, and the corresponding research production. This research production included 171 public presentations; 2 book chapters; 126 peer-reviewed publications 77 of which appeared in technical journals; and four large WESEP-organized events (1 conference, 2 symposia, and 1 workshop) on the ISU campus.

Highlights of this research included (1) design of a national high voltage transmission overlay to reduce the cost of reaching a 50% by-energy renewable penetration level; (2) development of a new aluminium/calcium composite material and deployment for high voltage direct current transmission conductors to reduce cost of building the kind of overlay identified in item #1;  (3) design of a hexcrete 140ft tall tower to increase energy production per turbine; (4) new ways of efficiently detecting damage on turbine blades via image processing methods and by deploying a new "sensing skin"; (5) development of a wireless sensor network for smart monitoring and managing of wind farms; (6) development of a new turbine blade design method using isogeometric structural analysis; (7) new numerical methods for solving the Navier-Stokes equations to characterize air flow throughout a wind farm; (8) deploying numerical weather prediction models to predict wind ramping events; (9) a compact permanent magnet wind turbine generator design using a Halbach cylinder; (10) development and validation of a method to predict aeroelastic loads/response of wind turbine blades through wind tunnel tests for damage and flutter predictions; (11) replication of the dynamics of offshore environments in a dry-boundary layer wind tunnels using motion simulators; (12) development of an optimization approach to perform integrated transmission and generation design under uncertainty; (13) design of a new dual-rotor wind turbine to  mitigate aerodynamic ineffciencies in the blade root region near the hub and losses due to aerodynamic interactions between turbines in a wind farm; (14) use of statistical data processing to predict wind turbine lifetimes and identify  related maintenance needs; and (15) design of owl-inspired airfoils for low noise turbine operation. 

In addition, the WESEP Ph. D. program established four new graduate courses in wind energy and a new Wind Energy Systems laboratory to support WESEP-related research and coursework. These courses not only provide WESEP-focused training, but they do so with an interdisciplinary approach that teaches students to think across traditional disciplinary boundaries. 

Broader impacts of this IGERT program include the impact of students taking the real-time research collaborative course WESEP 594 each and every semester of the program, resulting in over 200 meetings of this class throughout the project's duration. In this 1 hour per week course, students were exposed to state-of-art research topics and methods together with training in professional ethics, science and engineering communication to the media, environmental impacts, and policy development. In addition, 10 out of the 28 students spent 2-3 months studying overseas, widening their breadth of perspective both in terms of their research and in terms of their overall view of the US as an influence in the world. Over 25% of the 28 students were female or minority. Students made a concerted effort to engage with a number of communities, including local K-12 students and teachers through school visits. and ISU undergraduate programs throught the establishment of the Wind Energy Student Organization. Of particular interest, ISU supported an undergraduate group who participated in the  US Department of Energy Collegiate Wind Energy Competition in 2018 and 2019, winning the "Project Development Award" in 2019.
